Hi there! Over the past ten weeks, I've been familiarizing myself with the nature that is my backyard. I recorded my thoughts and feelings, taking photographs along the way. I've found it to be a pleasant experience. Being able to connect with nature reduces that isolation that many of us are feeling during the COVID-19 pandemic. If you are reading this, I hope my field journal helps you gain an appreciation for the little pockets of life around us.
Continue

Main Observation: Jujube Tree

This tree is a jujube tree. I only recently learned the name for it. In Vietnamese we call it trái táo tàu. A direct translation for that is Chinese apple. When ripe, the burnt red fruit it produces every year is succulent and sweet. Since we are in spring, I recorded overall changes in the tree over time.

  • April 3, 2020

    All Bark

    The deformed twisting pattern of this tree’s branches caught my eye. It looks completely dead; there is no trace of green on it at all. Spine-like twigs protrude from the thicker branches. I saw a large crow land on the tip of the tallest branch. I never realized how large those birds were. If it were an overcast day, this might have been an intimidating, almost sinister sight. But it’s a temperate seventy degrees and the sun is shining.

  • April 15, 2020

    First Leaves

    The jujube tree is starting to grow leaves. They appear in little clusters of about 5-10 leaves. It's crazy how fast this occurred after the last time I oberved the tree.

  • April 25, 2020

    More Leaves

    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. Sunt ut voluptatum eius sapiente, totam reiciendis temporibus qui quibusdam, recusandae sit vero unde, sed, incidunt et ea quo dolore laudantium consectetur!

  • May 2, 2020

    More and More Leaves

    Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. Sunt ut voluptatum eius sapiente, totam reiciendis temporibus qui quibusdam, recusandae sit vero unde, sed, incidunt et ea quo dolore laudantium consectetur!

  • May 16, 2020

    Cloudy Days Ahead

    The weather is overcast today. We've been cycling through weeks of hot and cold weather. There's even more leaves on the tree. It's slighhtly weird how the leaves are growing from the trunk near the bottom of the tree. Apparently, different cultivars have physically different growth patterns, so our tree possibly looks normal.

  • May 29, 2020

    Buds and Blooms

    It's starting to look more like a bush than a tree...The leaves are growing so close to the bottom that they conceal the trunk. I took a closer look, and there are some buds on the branches. A few of them bloomed into flowers. The flowers aren't very big; they must be around 8 millimeters. No fruit yet, although quick research tells me that jujubes have a relatively long flowering and fruiting period that extends all the way to fall.

Weeds

???

I'm still not sure what these are called, but I thought the weeds growing out of the concrete made for a cool image. I've never really given much thought to weeds before, so I enjoyed trying to find small things in nature. I think this really shows the tenacity of life, how it tries to survive even in places it shouldn't be able to. Although I'm sure my dad doesn't appreciate this. He is always telling us to go weed our yard.

Mentha spicata

  • Fun fact: Native spearmint is used to flavor toothpaste and dental hygiene products, whereas Scotch spearmint has a milder, more pleasant taste and is used in chewing gum and candies.

Mourning Dove

Zenaida macroura

4/28: A dove built a nest outside of our house! It is nested by our front door. My mom discovered it while sweeping and wondering where all the twigs on the floor came from. There was also a small broken egg on the floor, maybe the size of a golf ball. We are just leaving it alone for now.

5/22: Two baby birds hatched! My family isn't sure if this is when they were first born, but today is when we first noticed them. To me, they definitely look too big to be newly hatched, but I'm not too knowledgeable about that. They look a lot different than the mother dove. They are a much darker gray.

  • Fun fact: The bird is a strong flier, capable of speeds up to 55 mph.

Queen palm

Syagrus romanzoffiana
